fact.section: Difference in Treatment Outcome in Outpatients With Anxious Versus Nonanxious Depression: A STAR*D Report
fact.span: A total of 2,876 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder, enrolled from 18 primary and 23 psychiatric care sites, received citalopram in Level 1 of STAR*D.

issues: Span doesn't contain typical TREATS language

fact.span: The aim of citalopram treatment in Level 1 was to achieve symptom remission, which was defined as QIDS-C score ≤ 5.

issues: Condition not explicitly mentioned in span

fact.span: The primary outcome measure was the HAM-D score, obtained by research outcome assessors using telephone-based structured interviews at entry and exit from citalopram treatment.

issues: Condition not explicitly mentioned in span
Span doesn't contain typical IMPROVES language

fact.effect_size: lower remission rates compared to nonanxious depression
fact.span: patients with anxious depression were less likely to respond or to remit with citalopram treatment than those with nonanxious depression

issues: Span doesn't contain typical IMPROVES language

fact.span: Ms. D was started on a course of antidepressant therapy with citalopram... After 6 weeks of combined treatment with citalopram and a benzodiazepine, Ms. D reported a significant improvement in all her symptoms, and remission was achieved at the end of the 10th week of treatment.

issues: Condition not explicitly mentioned in span
